clean_story: Broken patterns.  Unexpected signals. "Glitch" comes from the German glitschen—to slip. It’s what happens when a system reveals its hidden layers, like a torn poster showing the wall beneath. Most see glitches as errors—–but they’re also unintended art. A corrupted JPEG isn’t just noise; it’s the image’s raw data bleeding through, pixels rearranged by faulty compression. In 1985, Nintendo’s Super Mario Bros. had a glitch called the "Minus World"—–a warped, underwater mirror of Level 1-2. Players didn’t complain. They mapped it. Shared codes to trigger it. Why?Glitches expose the rules of a system. A video game’s Minus World is like finding a secret door in your house—–proof the walls aren’t solid. In music, glitches become tools. Aphex Twin’s "Drukqs" (2001) used CD-skipping sounds as percussion. The error wasn’t fixed—–it was composed. Even in nature, "glitches" feel meaningful. A tree’s jagged lightning scar tells a story of survival. A DNA mutation might create a new trait—–or a disease. Three related subjects are error as creativity, systems hiding secrets, and how humans assign meaning.
